The Java Edition rendering engine is garbage, and only got worse with 1.14. I'm beginning to think Microsoft is trying to kill Java edition slowly to try to get everyone to move to their more monetized Bedrock edition.

The fact is, Vulkan rendering is possible in Minecraft. (Reference here)

However, many people who play minecraft (My sisters included) have computers that don't support Vulkan.

OpenGL is a powerful (If bloated) graphics library, the problem is bad rendering code and as of 1.15 Minecraft only uses OpenGL version 2.0 when 3.0 is actually older than Minecraft itself.
It could be a second backend that would coexist with the OpenGL one. Also it might be a good idea to use more modern OpenGL.
I agree with this - Vulkan needs to be an available, officially supported option for players.

I don't think this will be possible unless they decided to make a new edition of Minecraft with it or they'd just use DirectX 12 instead. Adding Vulkan support on the current java edition will just increase the game's size and players with entry-level pc's won't be able to play anymore and will also lead to war I guess also the effort it took for Mojang to rewrite Minecraft just for Bedrock Edition took years

Update: yeah it's possible to do it without rewriting Minecraft.

Rendering in 1.15 got abstracted away from the code itself and to be ready into Blaze3d, which is the rendering engine which minecraft will use.

 

My theory is that they will make different implementations of Blaze3D to be able to be used so that the user can use the best and fastest library once they make a Vulkan implementation.

Minecraft is running horrible on macOS!

With Vulkan and MoltenVK it would run really fast!

Minecraft bedrock is not an alternative!

I saw this somewhere, I think it was on reddit, but, if Mojang wanted to replace OpenGL, that would mean redo the entire code of the game. I also think that Terrain Generation does not have anything to do with OpenGL, since even if you have 12-24 Gb of ram for Minecraft, it is not going to get even close to what Bedrock can do. So, I only see Mojang needing to switch from OpenGL to, let's say, Vulkan, so we could have True Real Time RAY-Tracing, and RTX Acceleration. And, I don't see that many people wanting it (This is probably due to the fact that everyone thinks SEUS PTGI and Continuum RT are Ray Tracing Shaders, but they are not. They are Global Illumination. So, it won't get even close to what Bedrock RTX can do. Because of all of this, Mojang is probably not going to put the effort to change the rendering engine anytime soon, because not that many people want that to happen.

This is my theory

Minecraft Bedrock edition is not an alternative!

You can't stay forever in the past and a transition to Vulkan would be great and efficient for the future.

OpenGL or DirectX is not the future at all and should be removed.

Please Microsoft add Vulkan support and MoltenVK support for Minecraft and don't kill the Java edition!
up

Just some personal experience here.

8600K, RX 570 8Gb, 16Gb RAM, NVMe SSD, resolution: 1280x1024@75
Win10 Java 1.16.5 vanilla included Java8, max settings render distance 32: around 10-30 fps with huge lag spikes when the game flushes 3 gigabytes of memory every ten seconds

Debian Java 1.16.5 Sodium, Lithium, Hydrogen, Starlight with adopOpenJDK 16, max settings render distance 32: the lowest I get is 90, but it usually holds 150-200, underground is constant 600+ fps

Installing all this onto a Win10 will increase that 10-30 fps to about 70-80

For me, it is clear that, in fact it is NOT OpenGL's fault that a 2009 (okay, argue with me, but be it: a 2011) block game cannot perform on decent hardware. In my childhood, around 2016 someone flexed that they got 1000 fps in Minecraft, and it's indeed possible, still to this day if the coding team's goals weren't for code readibility or ease of use. Sure, moving over to Vulkan would be a great help (I personally highly recommend everyone that they should only learn Rust and Vulkan, instead of e.g. C++ or OGL/DX)

Porting Minecraft to Vulkan is a big deal, and they probably won't do it because 100% of the population didn't bought the latest RTX 9090 Ti SUPER with a 69 core 10 Ghz processor. What they could easily do is team up with the modders and figure out a solution: optifine already breaks a lot of mods, integrating it would mean nothing, as it would became the new standard; same for CaffeineMC.

Just my thoughts.
up this. i'm getting 30-40 fps with RX5700 and the problem is entirely OpenGL. Even with optifine and all other tweaks i get 100 max and i can't even go near using a shader.
Well... I get around 1000 FPS with my 5700xt so idk why you can't get 100FPS with your 5700. Also I can play with the highest Chocapic 13 shaders and still get 400FPS
I'm sorry, i dont believe you get 1000fps with an rx5700xt unless you're running at extremely low settings and at like 480p. At 1440p with a 3070ti I get 300-400 max without shaders.
Any update on Vulkan support?
They should make an option to either do vulkan or opengl so people on bad computers still play and it goes faster on newer computers

Could help multicore use and give bonus performance where possible instead of having an uneccessary ceiling, also would be really good if we could get Vulkan instead of DX12 as VK could help with console ports & even work better on SteamDeck. 

 --- 

In response to above: There would usually be multiple options when adding support for new API's (Waste of the old work otherwise, and allows for testing the new API)

I do know of a 2 projects adding Vulkan right now. One is on github and is heavily in beta, while the other is made by Continuum Graphics for their Continuum RT shaders. However this is still in beta and is unavailable to the public.

It would be a really big project and I think just sticking to OpenGL for a while if some optimisations are made. For instance chunks should be stored in RAM, which would be enough to increase the FPS by 100% if not more.

You can see there is tons of work yet to be done with OpenGL though, Sodium for instance is a light mod that introduces optimisations that can literally multiply your FPS by 5 times or more. Ferrite core is another mod that lowers your RAM usage, which would be very useful if chunks moved to RAM. 

There would be major benefits from moving to Vulkan, however the issue is that it would take far too much time, and better performance can be achieved by optimisations. Sure, there wouldn't be things like proper ray tracing support, however that can be left to shader developers until ray tracing becomes a standard option that isn't as intensive to run.

I think we agree that everyone can run minecraft with its basic graphics settings.

However shaders exists and they're amazing, and are another option to play with the game.

The "update" to vulkan is needed because the current game engine is to limited, and this change would only bring good things to the game.

I hope this thread will be one day under review...

I think Mojang needs to rewrite the entire rendering engine. But this engine should be abstract so that you can use different graphics APIs. Such as OpenGL support for older computers and Vulkan support for newer computers. This engine should also have batching, instanced rendering and other optimizations.

also I know mac is a minority and not important to them but it would be really nice if they could get it to run in metal 3

also it would be really nice if they could optimize their rendering even separately from that, like they do in bedrock edition, which is even faster than java with sodium

Software Developer here. And i just want to say that there is nothing wrong with OpenGL. Rendering is a tough process and just moving to Vulkan won't solve everyone's problems. All Vulkan really is, is a less abstracted interface for the GPU. OpenGL let's you do exactly the same as Vulkan, in less code.

The main reason Vulkan is faster for graphics, is actually just minor CPU overhead. In OpenGL you do less calls, but also have less controls, hence maybe it does stuff that you don't want/need.

Vulkan is no miracle drug that makes your GPU faster. OpenGL is already really fast, problem is, voxels are expensive to render. There are a lot of triangles being drawn, simply.

Memory usage is also high, simply because there is a lot to store. Let's say we store one short(16 bytes) to identify each block, to specify type. Then we have one HashMap(lookup table) for storing the identifiers for each of the type IDs, 0 being air, 1 being stone etc, and one ArrayList(list) for storing Tile Entities. Each chunk is 16x16x384(as of 1.18), which sums up to 98304 blocks. Each one of these blocks need 16 bytes each, summing up to 3145728 bytes, or 1536 kb, roughly 1 MB of RAM just for identifiers. A bunch of memory for identifiers and a bunch more for tile entities. Then you've got roughly 100 chunks loaded at a time, a bunch of textures and entities alongside memory preallocations. There is no way you can keep memory usage below maybe 2 GB.
However, it can be optimized. A lot.

Out of chars.

-- Jimmy

Yes I was going to create a feedback post on this but it turns out it's already posted I agree with this so much, especially since a lot of mobile devices (Android) have Vulkan APIs downloaded with them, and it would run so much better on mobile devices if it was supported.

Vulkan API really surpasses the outdated OpenGL in everything. The need for the latter has disappeared, since the new versions of Minecraft will not work fully on very old components anyway, while the rest have Vulkan support. 
Multiple tests have been performed, including by the mod community - Vulkan provides much higher performance and stability, which will positively affect optimization, error elimination and the quality of the gaming experience.

Vulkan is not supported on some computers and yes Vulkan is smoother than open gl but its more modern to use opengl and you see on bedrock edition when they switched to renderdragon a lot bugs were in the game and also you were not able to use shaders

Vulkan seems like a great idea, and it will speed up the rendering performance drastically on modern hardware. Maybe they could also implement Metal and improve shader performance (Fabulous graphics mode) on macOS.

How I think this should be done is you can choose between the Compatibility renderer (OpenGL) and the Fast renderer (Vulkan), I think that would be good if someones computer doesn't support Vulkan but they still would want to play.
My game almost goes to 5 FPS when I look in a certain direction in even a normal new world. It is clear Mojang needs to change the rendering engine, OpenGL 2 from 2004 is way too old.
It will be Minecraft 2.0

I think a good solution to this would be an experimental toggle option to be able choose between OpenGL and Vulkan for testing, so everyone who wants to use it can without locking anyone out of the game, like people with old/incompatible hardware.

Also development for OpenGL has ended years ago with them only operating on maintenance mode so there needs to be some kind of replacement eventually.

Also the relatively new Vulkan mod for Fabric is very promising and a good proof of concept so far.

I know this is several years later and probably have heard about it already, but there's a mod called "VulkanMod" which swaps OpenGL for Vulkan and I am happy to say it gives a huge performance boost. For me on my 2022 M2 MacBook Pro (8 Core CPU, 10 Core GPU, 8GB RAM), sodium has given me ~110FPS, which is good enough, but VulkanMod has given me ~560 FPS which is more than enough since my monitor only goes up to 240Hz while my mac display only does 60FPS. Vulkan is a lower level graphics API compared to OpenGL so it has a closer link to the hardware allowing for more versatile optimizations.

One thing people completely miss is that if Minecraft switched to Vulkan, it would completely break compatibility with ALL shaders and many graphical mods, making it unfeasible for Mojang to do. Everything would have to be remade from the ground up. Also OpenGL itself is not actually that bad, the more recent versions still hold up. Upgrading the version could enable enough improvements to be made

If this were changed, i think fish tanks and views from underwater bases would look a lot better.

Java edition of minecraft use Java and things made with it runs on a vm and because Java's vm doesn't support wayland monjag/microsoft can't really make a wayland version. The only thing they would be able to do is to make the launcher support wayland.
Definitly possible as just patching the Glfw library for mineccraft allows you to run native Wayland. This would be a very easy fix. Glfw supports wayland natively in it's newer versions.
This should be no brainer, to my knowledge all it involves would be enabling it and of course doing a little bit of testing
I would love this!!! Please!

Yess id love wayland support on Minecraft :)

Nvidias 555.58 driver has made wayland rather stable and usable for most people and well amd, intel work on wayland rlly well, desktops like kde plasma, gnome, cosmic rust desktop are all using wayland by default and desktops like cinnamon/linux mint are working on wayland support slowly so this should get supported as it solves those problems
Please consider updating Minecraft to support the Wayland display server protocol. This update would greatly improve performance and user experience for Linux users.

This would be awesome!
Especially because almost every Linux Distro has moved to Wayland by now.

Third party launchers such as PrismLauncher already allow you to use the system-installed version of GLFW, which will allow you to use Wayland if the system-installed version of GLFW has support for Wayland, so I figure it wouldn't be to difficult for the game to support Wayland out of the box. The tech is there, would love to see this in the base game!

you can adjust brightness (thats basicly gamma)

Agreed about how a Gamma slider should be added. There's a Brightness slider, but no Gamma one. Brightness is not the same thing, nor does it achieve the same result, as Gamma.

For example, I have Brightness cranked to 100 (max) here in this long staircase hallway I'm going down in "The Observer" (RTX) map, but can't see anything in the blacks. Gamma would let you lift the blackpoint up to at least see some details in the virtually zero-black areas...

I know the map is supposed to be dark and mysterious, but this is too dark; practically unplayable in this part. A Gamma slider would help.
I also fully agree! Bedrock needs Java or Console sunsets/sunrises and lighting improvements. Please make it true guys
This is a great idea I have wanted this for a long time. This should be in the game.

> First of all, I noticed that there wasn't a gamma controller, which made the lighting of the surroundings slightly dark

> And lastly; snow biomes ARE JUST, SOOOO BRIGHT!!!

That's just how it's intended to be. Lighting usually looks the best at the lowest gamma setting anyway, and snow is supposed to be bright, because it's nearly solid white and would thus be very bright, even in real life.

We know that community shaders are not supported anymore because of the upgrade to Render Dragon.

However, there are still a lot of people out there playing Minecraft without a RTX card, including the ones on smartphone, xbox, switch and so on...

The full upgrade to Render Dragon affected a lot of people who were playing Minecraft using a shader pack, because shaders packs greatly increase the look of the game, and make it more appreciated by players.

Because of that, many players who had taken the habit to use shaders packs stopped playing (including me). For example I have a good GC (GTX 1080ti) and I can't play with beautiful graphics since you upgraded to Render Dragon because the shaders pack I used made a lot of improvements.

 

Here are potential solutions/improvements :

1) Make community shaders compatible with Render Dragon

  -> If you are afraid of compatibility with RTX, you could maybe think about something like "if a RTX pack is loaded and RTX is activated, then disable shaders, otherwise let the shaders be loaded".

2) Add a video menu option to select whether to use Render Dragon or the previous engine

  -> This could be a solution but it will force you to support 2 graphics engine, not the best solution I think
i really hope they fix this ive downloades so many shaders recently and were confused on why they wouldnt work

This seems like a important if not critical feature adding that would expand raytracing and modding to more devices like the steam deck or consoles, without being limited to Nvidia hardware, not only that, but minecraft should logically be the perfect graphics style candidate to implement upscaling and sharpening technology.

I sadly hold no candle given that the suggestion has likely been shelved by whoever team reads these, given the age of the post. But the benefits are major, and introducing it would actually yield bigger results for much less costly dev time on bedrock as a performant alternative, the upscaling being able to be introduced to all mobile and portable devices, I boldly state.

If the implementation of the technology has as many performance benefits as it seems, FSR 3.0 is also the perfect opportunity for Mojang to ditch bedrock and get out of the bedrock/java validation/re-coding misfortune, if that's a giant hurdle against developing and testing new game content and features.

As HDR monitors become more and more common place, it will be extremely important for Minecraft to natively support HDR. The ability to disable color clamping during the rendering process would open up a world of visual improvements. Things like sunlight being significantly brighter than torch light. Night vision being able to make all light brighter, and not just making dark the same as normal light. HDR textures so that lamp blocks can have significantly brighter pixels. All this can be done by just changing various internal formats.

Please Mojang, we need this!
The moving color gradients that are visible during sunrise and sunset would be much smoother with HDR (I think...).
In Windows 10 Insider Preview Build 21337+, Auto HDR was brought over from Xbox, and works in Minecraft

HDR support in minecraft would be INCREDIBLE

I mean, win 10 edition already supports ray tracing (Java does too if you use optifine + shaders, but integrated support would be such a power move), so if we also add HDR support, then experience of minecraft would be hundreds of times better. I also wonder, if an HDR support update was a thing, then would it be accompanied with some really colorful features, like peafowls, opal stones, revamped parrots, chameleons, etc.?

In my opinion, even standalone HDR update is going to be one of the best updates!

HDR displays are becoming increasingly common and more and more people have to deal with a version of Minecraft that looks much more dull than other apps and causes the entire display to dim after closing whenever you play in fullscreen, requiring you to disable and re-enable HDR.

I'm onto my 3rd monitor with HDR. The last two use 10 bit color. And my new one pushes 1,400 nits. This stuff isn't new. And I have a mid-tier gaming rig. It's not even about supporting cutting edge anymore, it's about making the title not look like garbage. The new vibrant visuals for example doesn't even properly support 10bit/HDR yet, it's crazy, I can't even play the new update. I loaded it up, complained about it for 10 minutes and turned it off. I'm not touching that garbage. It looks so bad next to any other game. It's so dark and the banding is beyond belief.
This is honestly essential, every time I tab out my screen goes back as it switches back to 30 bit.
